bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, July 16, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses the planned publication of his speech and reproductions of the Cornwell painting in "Hygeia" and the "New York Sunday Mirror."

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, July 16, 1941
div1.opener:
July 16, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
I was delayed in writing Fishbein because of the press of work.
Enclosed is a copy of the letter I am sending him today. I have purposely left
certain obvious suggestions to you. I would suggest that you write him speci-
fically, assuming that they are going to include my introductory remarks about
Cornwell and the painting as a separate note to be included in the news item
to go with the colored inserts. I suggest you also assume, from his statement,
“We would then include that material in a separate item to accompany the re-
production of the painting and the photographs” that he may be using also either
the newspaper photograph of Van Etten, Reed and Lahey or the one of Cornwell,
Reed, Kissinger and myself. You could ask him more specifically about this and
you may suggest that he may want to amplify the news item by publishing one or
two preliminary sketches. You see that I have deliberately refrained from men-
tioning these things heretofore, as I think the build up should come slowly
rather than attempting to swamp Fishbein. I have not intimated yet that you
had any intention of buying a large number of reprints of my talk to send with
each reproduction. I think this suggestion should come from you to Fishbein
via a request to him as to whether he is willing to sell you the generous num-
ber of reprints for such distribution with the proper reference given “Reprinted
(with or without additions) from Hygeia.” In other words, I would suggest that
you write him saying that I have told you that they were reprinting my article,
that they were willing to use the inserts and that in view of that, you were
wondering whether you could get enough reprints to send one out with each re-
production. You can put this in your letter as if it were an after-thought or
just a recent idea. I assume that you wish to have reprints of my article as
soon as possible and I think gentle pressure to that end might come from your
request for these reprints. You might say that you would like to have them
fairly soon.

Do you think that the early appearance of a colored reproduction
and story in the New York Sunday Mirror would interfere with Fishbein's plans?
You say that this is to come out late this month. I suppose there is not much
chance of Fishbein's seeing the New York Mirror anyhow, although if there is a
medical article it might come to his attention. Do you think this might change
his plans? Do you think he might prefer to have it appear first in Hygeia and
to have you postpone the appearance of the New York Sunday Mirror story. In
this matter you will have to decide which is more important, a medical circulation
Mr. George A. Kellogg
- 2 -
July 16, 1941
with one hundred twenty-five thousand copies or a layman circulation with two
million copies. I am glad it is your decision and not mine. Maybe I am unduly
concerned and maybe the appearance of neither will conflict with that of the
other. I shall be anxious to see the proofs of the reproduction at your
earliest convenience.

Incidentally, I hear that Kissinger is improving slowly but
is still pathetically ill and that Blossom's trouble was largely nervous,
although she is being taken care of “tenderly” by very sympathetic friends
and relatives.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
